solution_line_template: John runs {total_race_distance}-{john_initial_distance}=<<{total_race_distance}-{john_initial_distance}={john_remaining_distance}>>{john_remaining_distance} meters once he reaches his max speed
So he runs at a speed of {john_remaining_distance}/{john_remaining_time}=<<{john_remaining_distance}/{john_remaining_time}={john_speed}>>{john_speed} m/s
So that means James's top speed is {john_speed}+{james_speed_increase}=<<{john_speed}+{james_speed_increase}={james_top_speed}>>{james_top_speed} m/s
He has to run {total_race_distance}-{james_initial_distance}=<<{total_race_distance}-{james_initial_distance}={james_remaining_distance}>>{james_remaining_distance} meters at his top speed
So he runs that at {james_remaining_distance}/{james_top_speed}=<<{james_remaining_distance}/{james_top_speed}={james_remaining_time}>>{james_remaining_time} seconds
So he takes {james_remaining_time}+{james_initial_time}=<<{james_remaining_time}+{james_initial_time}={james_total_time}>>{james_total_time} seconds to run 100 meters
